title.narrative: Programming Their Future

description.narrative: PTF stands for Programming Their Future. Programming Their Future will be an ICT Outsourcing platform, assisting in both connecting between Palestinian programmers and Dutch Companies and establishing ecosystem to support and promote such activities for 3rd parties. The company will operate internationally and will be mainly operating out of the Netherlands while maintaining strong ties to the Palestinian Territories.

activity-date.narrative:
Due to unforeseen circumstances, our program started 3 months later. Immediately when we knew it we contacted NRO to inform about this delay and it was mutually agreed to wait until the need of the program to ask for an extension. At this stage it has our preference to agree with you to reach an agreement on an extension of PTF as soon as possible.
Since we could not foresee these circumstances, we kindly request our PTF program to have neutral budget extend to July 1st 2020. This is more than 3 months but reflects the actual need of the program
Due to unforeseen circumstances, the implementation of our program started 3 months later.

This final narrative report provides the PTF activities in addition to the update of June 2020. From May 1st, 2020 the delays incurred are the result of both the Corona situation and the termination of employment with Sales. Due to these circumstances an approval for a budget neutral extension request was received from July 1st until December 31st, 2020. Waiting for approval, we used this period to (re) focus on continuing to create further awareness, maintain current contacts /activities, administration (yearly reports etc.) and look for a suitable Sales candidate/ opportunities. All activities were still based on achieving signed contracts and take proper preparations to proceed after approval of the extension request and hiring a new Sales Representative in NL. After approval, which we received on August 5th, 2020, and active recruitment, we found and hired per September 1st a new Sales Representative in NL. This resulted in the first signed contract before end of December! 2. Lessons learned Sales needed to be further organized and the Importance of having a good Sales team member – although the general ideas is good, someone needed to translate it to actual sales in a very focused way. Use nearshoring as a service instead of outsourcing and group our services search for prospects in start-ups was not the best approach. Mid-size companies with approved budget are the most suitable targeted segment. The prices offered are still attractive and Palestinian companies are willing even to reduce pricing where needed (with the exception of ASAL). The combination of our chairman as door opener and John to follow up seems to work well. Websites misses 'use cases' which we will be added asap in year 2. COVID hits us all and resulted in creative solutions and new possibilities

recipient-country.narrative: PTF's first goal is to bridge between businesses in the Netherlands who are looking to outsource and connect them with qualified programmers in the Palestinian territories. Our second goal is to create an ecosystem of users and service providers that will ultimately also facilitate the transformation of knowledge from Dutch highly experienced engineers directly to the programmers and students in the Palestinian territories. Part of the first few months of the program will also be to deepen our knowledge on what skillsets are needed on the Palestinian side. Thus the company will run two main activities: 1) Promoting, attracting and engaging with Dutch companies who would welcome Palestinian programmers and 2) Creating a platform to promote the Dutch/PT ICT collaboration through ICT missions and in year 2 and 3 also arranging internships.

sector.narrative: Many Dutch companies prioritize their efforts on their ‘core business’, therefore outsourcing their IT programming to specialized IT businesses. The number of companies that outsource their IT programmers is increasing, especially in the middle and small size sector (SME). In the Netherlands, there is a shortage of well-educated and enough specialized personnel. As result many companies are looking for an outsourcing solution. Dutch companies tend to outsource through long term contracts, mainly to India and Eastern Europe. Middle size companies are searching for ‘near shore’ locations. The Palestinian territories are relatively unknown to Dutch companies as an outsourcing location. Palestinians programmers are more loyal, than workers from distant countries and have a dogged work ethic, many gained experience working abroad, and stiff competition for jobs in the West Bank, pushes those who have work to prove themselves.The Palestinian ICT professionals have very good language skills in English and Arabic. English is the language of instruction in major science based courses. The NRO in Palestine already has been involved in some ICT projects in the Palestinian territories building an inclusive and supportive technology ecosystem which is enabling creation of income and jobs for young people and women. Such actions bring employment, reconciliation and stability to this region. When interviewing some of NRO initiatives and other 3rd parties who are active in this field it was understood that the missing link to a very powerful collaboration between the Netherlands and the Palestinian programmers is the way the programmers will be presented and connected to the Dutch companies.
